I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  Bhutan  has  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for 
assistance to strengthen the capacity of the Department of Labour (DOL) of the Ministry of 
Labour and Human Resources (MLHR) to implement the Labour and Employment Act (the Act) 
and related rules and regulations.1 An ADB fact-finding mission2 visited Bhutan on 5–7 October 
2005 to discuss the technical assistance (TA), and agreed on the TA design, activities, outputs, 
financing and implementation arrangements, and consultants’ terms of reference. Because of 
the delay in the approval of the labor administration policy and submission of the Act to the 
National Assembly, the TA was postponed and is now in the TA program for Bhutan for 2007. A 
consultation mission3 visited Bhutan on 12–14 September 2006 to validate and update, where 
necessary, the design, activities, outputs, financing, and implementation arrangements, and 
consultants’  terms  of  reference. 4  The  mission’s  findings  and  understandings  with  the 
Government formed the basis for formulating the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Bhutan’s development strategy, as presented in the Ninth Five Year Plan 2002–2007 
(and in the Eighth Five Year Plan) identifies the private sector as the main source of future 
income generation and job creation opportunities. However, the private sector has been slow to 
assume this role because of, among others, the lack of physical infrastructure, the narrow skills 
base, weak financial institutions, the absence of a regulatory framework, and the reluctance of 
youth, both skilled and unskilled, to join the private sector. The policy document, A Vision for 
Peace, Prosperity and Happiness (Bhutan 2020 Vision), identifies a number of reasons for the 
last reason, including low respect for the dignity of labor, the failure to see real growth in the 
private sector, doubts about career prospects, job insecurity, and bad overall working conditions, 
including poor occupational health and safety (OHS).  
 
3.  To encourage youth to join the private sector, an effective labor administration system 
and legal framework is needed. In keeping with the country’s guiding principles, as outlined in 
Bhutan 2020 Vision, private sector growth must strike a balance between economic efficiency to 
ensure sustainability and competitiveness of enterprises, and social justice and equity to ensure 
the fair treatment and adequate protection of workers. Finding and maintaining that balance falls 
within the responsibilities of the MLHR and, more specifically, with the DOL.  
 
4.  Against this background, ADB provided TA 3790-BHU for Institutional Development of 
the Department of Employment and Labour,5 which at that time was part of the Ministry of 
Health  and  Education.  The  TA’s  overall  objective  was  to  strengthen  labor  administration. 
Specific objectives included (i) developing a comprehensive labor administration policy, (ii) 
strengthening the capacity of the Department of Employment and Labour (DEL) and its staff to 
become  the  lead  agency  in  labor  administration,  and  (iii)  developing  the  legal  framework 
necessary for DEL to fulfill its mandate. TA outputs were (i) a draft policy document, Labour 
Administration:  Finding  a  Balance,  including  a  master  plan  to  establish  the  MLHR  and  a 
                                                 
1 The TA was originally included in the TA program for 2005 under the title: TA for Implementing the Labour and 
Employment Act.

2   
National Employment Policy; (ii) a staff desk manual covering several technical areas of labor 
administration and various areas of skills development; (iii) a draft labour and employment act; 
(iv) an initial in-house training program for DEL staff; (v) workshops to discuss (i) and (iii); and 
(vi) the organization of the first job fair in Bhutan.  
 
5.  The labor administration policy together with the master plan directly helped transform 
the DEL into the MLHR. Several components of the labor administration policy as well as its 
implementation mechanism were de facto endorsed at an early stage. This was evidenced by 
the structural arrangements of the newly established MLHR, by the formal endorsement of the 
MLHR staffing plan, by the conduct of several job fairs, and by the establishment of a one-stop 
shop for employment matters. In July 2006, the Council of Ministers formally approved the 
Labour Administration Policy, firmly anchoring the mandate of the MLHR in areas such as labor 
inspection, labor administration, and OHS.  
 
6.   The Council of Ministers endorsed the draft Labour and Employment Act in mid-October 
2006 after some delays arising from a cautious approach to ensure consistency between the 
Act and the Constitution, which is proposed to be submitted to the National Assembly during its 
summer session of 2008. The National Assembly enacted the Labour and Employment Act on 5 
January 2007. To ensure high compliance with all labor legislation, continued awareness raising, 
information and advice is needed, and inspection and enforcement must be developed and 
supported. 
 
7.  Moreover, cognizant of the need for a strong legal framework, the Council of Ministers 
approved in July 2006 two sets of rules and regulations prepared by the DOL, based on the 
draft Act. One is Rules and Regulations Governing Employment Agencies in Bhutan, 2006, and 
the other General Rules and Regulations on Occupational Health and Safety in Construction, 
Manufacturing, Mining and Service Industries, 2006.  The Government has requested the ADB 
for  assistance  to  improve  existing  rules  and  regulations, to  draft  additional  legislation  and 
standards, and to train DOL staff to implement and supervise these rules and regulations. 
Implementing rules and regulations covering several other areas of the Act also need to be 
drafted. These include, for example, rules and regulations related to labor inspection, labor–
management relations, as well as dispute prevention and settlement. 
 
8.  In  line  with  the  approval  of  the  MLHR  staffing  plan  by  the  Royal  Civil  Service 
Commission, 10 labor inspectors and 2 labor relations officers have been recruited and are in 
place. The inspectors, who are fresh graduates, need to be trained in the nature, purpose, and 
techniques of an integrated labor inspection system in a small country. Procedural manuals as 
well as reporting instruments to assess enterprises’ compliance with labor and employment-
related legislation also need to be developed. In view of the complete novelty of labor inspection 
and the lack of experienced labor inspectors who can serve as role models, in-country training 
must be complemented with training activity in the region, giving the new recruits a better 
understanding of what labor inspection entails and how it functions in the field. Labor relations 
officers must also be trained to ensure compliance with the Act’s labor–management provisions, 
and to promote sound and constructive worker–management relations at the enterprise level. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be to further strengthen the labor administration system, 
thereby  contributing  to  the  growth  of  the  private  sector  as  a  viable,  promising,  and  safe

3
employment alternative to the public sector. The expected outcome will be that workers and 
employers have increased access to an efficient, effective, and transparent labor administration 
system.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Key activities under the TA include (i) activities to enhance the legal framework, (ii) 
capacity development for DOL staff, and (iii) strengthened institutional arrangements to ensure 
labor legislation compliance.  
 
11.  Activities that will enhance the legal framework include the following:  
(i)   Together  with  the  DOL  legal  officer,  a  series  of  labor-related  rules  and 
regulations to implement the Act will be drafted, issued, and applied. Priority 
areas will be decided in close cooperation with the DOL director, but will include 
at least labor inspection, labor–management relations, and dispute prevention 
and settlement. 
(ii)   Based  on  a  comprehensive  survey  and  assessment  of  OHS  in  industries, 
construction, and manufacturing, the existing OHS rules and regulations will be 
revised, a  comprehensive OHS policy prepared, and detailed standards and 
codes of behavior developed. 
(iii)   Public awareness materials on the Act and the rules and regulations will be 
prepared and distributed. 
 
12.  Capacity development activities will focus on training labor inspectors and labor relations 
officers, as well as other stakeholders as appropriate. These activities will include the following:  
(i)   Training of at least 10 labor inspectors, operating under an integrated inspection 
system, will involve training-room, on-site, and online instruction and activities. 
To ensure that inspectors can apply the acquired knowledge and skills, the TA 
will support the purchase of basic equipment to measure noise, heat, humidity, 
dust, and illumination.  
(ii)   To complement in-country training, the new labor inspectors will be exposed to 
the workings of an integrated inspectorate in a country in the region through a 
regional  training  activity  under  the  supervision  of  the  labor  administration 
consultant.  
(iii)   At  least  four  labor  relations  officers  will  be  trained  to  improve  worker–
management relations at the enterprise level, including to prevent and settle 
disputes. For part of this training, employers and employee representatives will 
be invited to participate.  
 
13.  To strengthen the institutional arrangements, the TA will do the following:  
(i)   Help prepare and test procedural manuals, templates for labor inspection report 
forms and related documents such as noncompliance notices and improvement 
and prohibition notices, as well as templates for conciliation, mediation, and 
related  reports.  The  templates’  formats  will  be  discussed  with  stakeholders 
before finalization.  
(ii)   Help the DOL draw up its inputs into the 10th Five Year Plan. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $340,000 equivalent, of which ADB will provide 
$300,000 to finance consulting services, training and workshops, the production of desk books,

4   
training materials and dissemination materials, an enterprise survey on OHS, the purchase of 
basic  equipment  kits  for  labor  inspectors,  and  a  regional  training  activity.  The  TA  will  be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  TA  funding  program.  The  Government’s  contribution, 
estimated at $40,000 equivalent, will be in kind and will include office accommodation and 
transport for field visits, counterpart staff remuneration, and miscellaneous administrative and 
support services. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The DOL will be the Executing Agency, and a senior staff member of the DOL will be 
appointed focal person for the TA.  
 
16.  The TA will require a total of 12 person-months of consultants’ services (10 person-
months’  international  and  2  person-months’  national  consultants).  The  consultants  will  be 
individually recruited in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (April 2006, 
as amended from time to time). One international consultant with extensive experience in labor 
administration;  labor  administration  skills  development  and  training;  and  preparation  of 
regulations, guidelines, and outreach materials will be engaged for a total of 7 person-months 
spread over three periods during the TA. The DOL has requested ADB to use single-source 
selection to recruit the labor administration consultant who assisted the DOL under TA 3790-
BHU, in view of his knowledge and understanding of the Bhutanese context and his extensive 
experience with labor administration, and because the current TA is a continuation of the work 
done under TA 3790-BHU. The labor administration consultant will accompany, as trainer, the 
labor inspectors on their regional training and will act as the team leader for the TA. 
 
17.  A second international consultant, with extensive experience in preparing OHS policies 
and experience in drafting OHS legislation and standards, will be recruited for 3 person-months. 
He or she will overlap for at least 6 weeks with the labor administration consultant to ensure 
consistency and complementarity in the training of the labor inspectors. He or she will be 
supported by a national consultant for 2 person-months to prepare and conduct a survey and 
assess the OHS situation. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  Equipment will be procured by the Government in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (April 2006, as amended from time to time). The TA will be implemented over 16 
months, from February 2007 to May 2008. The schedule of training activities will be agreed 
upon with the DOL and scheduled to ensure maximum attendance by DOL staff. Stakeholders 
will be consulted on all regulations prepared under the TA.  
 
19.  The labor administration consultant will submit a brief inception report to the DOL and 
ADB within 3 weeks after activities start, which will include a work plan with a proposed time 
frame for all activities, including for regional training. He will submit a draft final report by the 
middle  of  the  third  stint  and  a  final  report  on  conclusion  of  the  assignment.  The  OHS 
international consultant will submit a brief inception report to the DOL and ADB within 3 weeks 
after activities start, a brief status report at the end of month two, and a final report when the 
assignment ends.

5
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for Capacity Development for the Department of Labour, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will recruit three individual consultants for a total of 12 
person-months (10 for international and 2 for national consultants). The international consultants 
will consist of (i) a labor administration consultant, who will focus on labor inspection and labor 
relations; and (ii) an occupational health and safety (OHS) consultant. The national consultant will 
help the international OHS consultant prepare and conduct an OHS survey.  
A.  Labor Administration Consultant (international, 7 person-months intermittently) 
 
2.  Under the supervision of the director of the Department of Labour (DOL), Ministry of Labour 
and Human Resources (MLHR), the consultant will do the following: 
(i)  Draft regulations and guidelines or codes of conduct, and facilitate discussions with 
stakeholders, on the following: 
(a)  powers and obligations of labor inspectors, 
(b)  improvement and prohibition notice procedures, 
(c)  contravention: sanctions and penalties, 
(d)  workplace rules/internal regulations, 
(e)  worker misconduct, 
(f)  leave arrangements (including maternity leave), 
(g)  workers’ committees: election and operations, 
(h)  workplace cooperation, 
(i)  collective bargaining procedures, and 
(j)  dispute settlement procedures (grievance procedure, conciliation, arbitration). 
Priorities will be determined in consultation with the director, DOL. 
(ii)  Prepare  procedural  manuals,  templates  of  labor  inspection  report  forms  and 
noncompliance  notices—based  on  an  integrated  inspection  system—as  well  as 
templates for conciliation and mediation reports. Conduct seminars and workshops 
with key stakeholders before their finalization. 
(iii)  Plan,  organize,  and  conduct  a  series  of  training  activities  for  at  least  10 labor 
inspectors, operating under an integrated system and in accordance with the Labour 
and  Employment  Act  (the  Act),  involving  training-room,  on-site,  and  online 
instruction and activities. 
(iv)  Accompany, as trainer, the labor inspectors on their regional training activity. 
(v)  Plan and organize a series of training activities for labor relations officers, employers, 
and  worker  representatives  on  approaches  to  improving  labor–management 
cooperation at the enterprise level. 
(vi)  Prepare  training  materials  to  support  the  training  of  labor  inspectors  and  labor 
relations officers. 
(vii)  Prepare desk manuals to assist and support labor inspectors in their day-to-day 
work. 
(viii)  Together  with  the  chief  labor  inspector,  plan  and  conduct  a  series  of  1-day  
seminars/discussion sessions to promote employer awareness of the legislation and 
procedures relating to labor inspection. 
(ix)  Draft a series of articles on the Act for inclusion in Kuensel and other newspapers. 
(x)  Draft a series of public awareness pamphlets on particular aspects of the Act. 
 
3.  The consultant will work closely with other international and national consultants, and plan 
and implement the training of the inspectors in close cooperation with the OHS consultant. The 
labor  administration  consultant  will  be  the  team  leader  and  coordinate  inputs  from  other

10   Appendix 3 
 
consultants. The work will be done in close consultation and cooperation with the chief labor 
inspector  to  encourage  the  maximum  transfer  of  skills  and  knowledge.  The  regulations  and 
guidelines will be drafted in close cooperation with the DOL legal officer.  
 
B.  Occupational  Health  and  Safety  (international,  3  person-months;  national,  2  person-
months)  
 
4.  Under the supervision of the DOL director, and in cooperation with those responsible for 
OHS in other ministries and agencies, the international consultant will do the following: 
(i)  Provide guidance and inputs to the national consultant for the preparation and 
conduct of a survey and assessment of the OHS situation in industry, construction, 
and manufacturing. 
(ii)  Draft a national OHS policy. 
(iii)  Refine  and  supplement,  as  necessary,  the  rules  and  regulations  on  OHS  in 
construction, manufacturing, mining, and services. 
(iv)  Prepare guidelines to help enterprises prepare an OHS policy as required under the 
Labour and Employment Act. 
(v)  Draft detailed standards, codes of behavior, and other guidelines on various aspects 
of OHS, as required, including on (a) all aspects of building and construction; (b) 
materials handling and storage, with a particular emphasis on chemicals; and (c) 
machine safety. 
(vi)  Help train labor inspectors in meeting OHS compliance and reporting requirements. 
(vii)  Prepare training materials on the OHS components of an integrated labor inspection 
system. 
(viii)  Draft a series of articles on OHS for inclusion in Kuensel and other newspapers. 
(ix)  Draft a series of public awareness pamphlets on particular aspects of OHS. 
(x)  With  the  labor  administration  consultant,  conduct  a  sample  OHS  inspection  of 
construction sites, at Thimphu and one or two manufacturing industries in Pasakha. 
 
5.  The consultant is expected to work closely with other international and national consultants, 
particularly with the labor administration consultant, to train inspectors, and with the domestic 
consultant to prepare and conduct the survey. The rules and regulations as well as guidelines will 
be drafted in close cooperation with the DOL legal officer, while the OHS policy will be prepared in 
close cooperation with the DOL policy officer. 
6.  The national consultant, under the guidance and supervision of the international consultant 
on OHS, will be responsible for preparing and conducting a survey and for assessing the OHS 
situation in industry, construction, and manufacturing
